name: diethylsilane
Reason: The basic unit in this context is silane (SiH4), which has a melting point of -185°C. The addition of ethyl groups raises the melting point due to an increase in molecular weight and van der Waals forces. Each ethyl group (–CH2CH3) contributes to the melting point increase compared to hydrogen atoms in silane. For similar compounds, an ethyl group can typically increase the melting point by roughly +26.5°C per group when averaged for this prediction. Diethylsilane has two ethyl groups, so the combined effect of two ethyl groups is approximately 2 x (+26.5°C).
Test (Predicted reason):
- Basic unit, ethane, has a melting point of -183°C.
- Ethyl groups: Each ethyl group (–CH2CH3) adds to the molecular weight and van der Waals interactions, which typically increases the melting point. We estimate each ethyl group to raise the melting point by about +20°C.
- Silicon atom: The introduction of a silicon atom into the molecule adds significant rigidity and increases the molecular weight, which can raise the melting point. We estimate the effect of the silicon atom to be about +30°C.
- Methylene bridge: The methylene bridge (–CH2–) between the silicon and the ethyl groups adds some rigidity and molecular weight, which can further raise the melting point. We estimate this effect to be about +5°C.
- Total estimated increase: 20 (ethyl group) + 30 (silicon atom) + 5 (methylene bridge) = 55°C.
